trim.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to make something look neater by cutting small pieces off it
trim.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Pete was trimming the lawn around the roses.
I have my hair trimmed every six weeks.
Trim away any excess glue with a knife.
trim.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to reduce a number, amount, or the size of something
trim.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We need to trim costs by £500m.
The bill would trim the number of immigrants to the US.
The company trimmed £46,000 from its advertising budget.
trim.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to decorate something, especially clothes, by adding things that look pretty
trim.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: At Christmas, the whole family helps trim the tree.
trim.translation[0].definitions[2].note_: Trim is often passive in this meaning
trim.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to move the sails of a boat in order to go faster
trim.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a person who is trim is thin in an attractive healthy way
trim.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: I play tennis to keep trim.
trim.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: when something is cut to make it look neater
trim.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: additional decoration on a car, piece of clothing etc
trim.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to remove parts of a plan, set of activities, company etc in order to reduce its costs
trim.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: We need to trim the Defence budget by another £500m.
The company is to trim its workforce  (=reduce the number of people it employs) by 10%.
Stock has shot up 54 percent this year as the firm trimmed its debt and narrowed its focus on the healthcare industry.
